reviews.content:
The good: overall this is a 5 star product, the design team did a great job on it, it has the most and the best features available today, it is very adjustable, it looks great and doesnt take up too much space and it gives you an excellent workout. I compared the simulation on Zwift to real life and, the way this bike handles changes in terrain and adjusts the load is outstanding, to the point that I had the same level of tiredness over the same distance on a flat course as I do in real life, even the speeds generally matched what I get in real life data. Having said this, the downhill simulation is the only place its not perfect in that regard, it doesnt quite feel right, the flywheel doesnt seem to keep up with the simulation and, if you were rolling down a steep hill and stopped pedaling the system will spin down and the flywheel will eventually fully stop, even though in Zwift you are still rolling down and picking up speed. It doesnt seem to allow you to freewheel downhill properly. Im guessing that, if the motor is strong enough this can be fixed with software patches. Overall this is an outstanding exercise tool and worth the money hands down. I cant speak for long term reliability but, it feels like it should handle the virtual miles well. 

The bad: the seat that comes with the bike is terrible, dont even try to use it it will hurt you, just have a different seat right away and install it from the start. My particular bike had a lot of vibration and metallic buzzing at low rpm, at first I thought something inside was loose but, that was not the case. On the left side of the bike (left when sitting on it) is a plastic panel attached with a bunch of little Allen head screws, if you remove that panel you get access to the rear axle adjustment bolt (9/16th wrench), a circuit board and the cooling system. Now, the way they cool part of the system is by having a fan blowing through a metal wind tunnel, inside that wind tunnel are two metal coils/springs, the problem is that when certain vibrations hit those coils, they make a metallic buzzing sound like a screw rattling. The vibrations themselves came from the flywheel, it is a heavy flywheel and the rear axle adjuster is the oldschool "slider" type, you loosen the bolt and slide that side of the axle around a little bit changing the angle of the flywheel relative to the center line of the bike. Well, in my bike it wasnt adjusted correctly, the flywheel was slightly off center causing a lot of vibration, especially at low RPM, and those vibrations caused everything that could buzz to do so, after playing around with it I was able to center the flywheel a lot better and the vibration is now gone for the most part. So, if you get this bike and experience something like this thats how you fix it, the company doesnt have instructions yet so I wrote them for you here.
reviews.title: Some of the best excersise you can get at home.

motor.name: motor
motor.sentence: Im guessing that, if the motor is strong enough this can be fixed with software patches.

exercise.name: exercise
exercise.sentence: Some of the best excersise you can get at home.

reviews.content: Had been on a “dumb” turbo trainer previously, worked well but switching the bike out and preparing it to ride each time just meant I didn’t ride as often or have as much time on the bike. A dedicated trainer which takes up less space then the bike on the turbo trainer makes everything far easier. And the move to a smart trainer with ERG mode is a game changer for training.

reviews.content: I read and watched all the reviews for all the options for months before pulling the trigger. Zero regrets. Worth every penny. Easy to fine tune. It really is quiet. Pairs instantly and without issue. You're going to have an insane amount of packaging to get rid of when it arrives. Oh and im 6'1" with long legs/arms and short torso -I wish the vertical adjustment on the handlebars was capable of going a little higher, i have the seat post so high that Im stuck with mostly aggressive body position configurations. Its not an issue or a regret, as it still covers what my positioning is like on real bikes, i just wish i had the wiggle room for a more upright posture.

reviews.content: I bought the Kickr Bike Shift for its extensive fit adjustability, customizable virtual shifting, and smooth operation (seriously, it's butter-smooth). Although the Direct Drive trainer that I'd been using was fantastic, I didn't really have an adequate, properly sized trainer bike to use full-time with it. The price point and features of the Shift fit my needs/wants perfectly, and has definitely lived up to the reviews I saw/read prior to purchasing it. I use the Shift strictly for Zwift, so the discounted annual Zwift membership was a nice bonus. Quite honestly, I couldn't be happier with this purchase!
reviews.title: Excellent dedicated trainer for Zwift

reviews.content:
The bike is easy to set up and very quiet. The Zwift integration is completely seamless. The ride experience is great. The footprint is compact and the bike is attractive. I have it in my living room and it looks great.

The saddle is not at all comfortable, particularly for women. It would be good if they had gender specific saddles and you could choose at purchase, given the price of the bike, rather then force women to buy a specific saddle in addition to the bike.

The set up instructions in the manual could be better. But there are lots of resources on YouTube.

Having set it up, I am really enjoying it.

reviews.content:
Bike received, few usage marks but nothing unusual for a bike that has been used and reconditioned. 
Initial setup is quick and easy.
The road feel, climbing simulation are great and it seems more accurate than my previous direct drive home trainer.
No need to (dis)mount my road bike everytime i want to go outside/indoor, this is a massive gain in comfort for me.

Points that could be improved:
* Ratling noises from time to time
* Confort of the hood (too thin) and handle bar tape (it slips)
reviews.title: Reconditioned Kick Bike

reviews.content: Its been 5 years of no cycling due left hip injury (non- cycling). A month ago had hip replacement. Bought the kicker bike, head fan, and stand to recover and rebuild my health from surgery. I just started exercising on it and so happy in the investment. I adjusted the bike in a very upright position for now. And will gradually adjust more aggressively as I improve until it matches my road bike. That is awesome about the kicker bike. Train indoors all through the winter and early spring to be ready for next summer outdoors! Its quite and smooth. I'm excited for the journey ahead to become myself once again.

reviews.content: I had a kickr gen 2 smart trainer bought used for a couple years. My street bike has been fitted and is great IRL, but somehow was uncomfortable on the trainer. The Kickr Bike is super comfortable once all the settings are dialed in. Also, keeping my road bike in my car ready for IRL while having the Kickr Bike standing by if it rains means no setup to get a quick ride in.
